Betty hopes that in the future she will be able to become a doctor. 

Betty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Betty's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed

loans.name: Joan Rose

texts.en:
Joan Rose is a married woman who has two children. Joan Rose is 27 years old and lives in Panta-on, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. 

Joan Rose owns and operates a farm where she plants crops to earn a living. She has been in this business for three years. Each month, she earns 4,000 PHP doing this work. 

She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Joan Rose has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Joan Rose wants to build a house and to see her children finish school.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to open another drug shop.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 35 years old and is married with three children aged between five and ten years old.  He owns a boutique selling various goods such as lotions, soaps and biscuits.  Samuel has seventeen years' experience and the hours of his business are from 6am to 8pm every day except on the weekend.  He currently employs three people to help him.

Samuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase various goods such as lotions, soaps and biscuits to sell.  With any profits from the loan, Samuel would like to satisfy his family's basic needs, start saving for his future and renovate his house.

loans.use: to purchase various goods such as lotions, soaps and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Ammabille

texts.en:
Ammabile. a 36-year-old married mother of two children, has been operating a retail store that sells canned goods, detergents and batteries for two years now. As well, she and her husband own a motorcycle used to transport passengers in their village.

A member of HSPFI since 2007, Ammabile is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy stocks such as detergents, batteries and canned goods for the sari sari store and to pay for the maintenance of their motorcycle. In the future, she hopes to improve both her businesses and her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to pay for motorcycle maintenance and to buy additional items to sell in the sari sari store.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a 50-year-old widowed woman with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her business is selling first-hand clothes. She faces the challenge of customers not paying on time and inadequate capital to meet her customers' different preferences. Her personal goals are to build a permanent house and to educate her children. Her desire is to expand her business into a shopping mall. Stella needs money to buy new clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 18 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. For the last two years, Juliet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells charcoal.

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy charcoal for resale, and will help Juliet to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business.

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Juliet's future prospects by helping her to improving her business.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Shine On Group

texts.en:
Ruth is a cross-border trader who buys electrical goods from neighbouring countries and sells them in a local market near her home in Harare. She is 55 years old and has two children aged 24 and 28.

She has been in this business for six years and things are going well except that some customers are unable to pay for their orders. Her husband also sells goods in the local market. They have no other source of income. 

Ruth is requesting a loan of US $400 to buy electric gadgets for resale. In the near future, Ruth plans to to open a family shop.

loans.use: To buy electrical goods for resale.

loans.name: Ephantus

texts.en:
Ephantus is a farmer in Murang'a. He is 41 years old with 20 years of experience in farming. His farm currently produces milk and tea for the local market. He  runs a retail business in a nearby market in addition to farming. He is married with two children ages 13 and 7 years.

Ephantus has requested a loan of 63,600 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow to boost his dairy farming business. He hopes to improve his dairy breeds and earn more income, which will enable him to educate his children and improve her family's living standards.

Ephantus also mentions low prices for milk in the local markets as his main challenge.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zana, in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Annet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells products like sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase supplies for resale, and will help Annet to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her brother. Annet hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Annet's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for resale.

loans.name: Violette

texts.en:
Violette is 34 years old and is married with three children aged between six and twelve years old and she takes care of one child who is 25 years old. Violette owns a business selling wedding clothes.  This is her first successful year in this business and the hours of her work are from 7am until 8.30pm every day except on the weekend.  She currently employs one person to help her.

Violette has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by adding more wedding clothes for sale.  With any profits, she will be able to save for her future, will reinvest in her business and she will be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to expand her business by adding more wedding clothes for sale.

loans.name: Love One Another Group

texts.en:
Chipo is 37 years old and lives in Gweru. As a family they have two children aged 22 and 17. One child is still at school. They have no other dependants.

Chipo is into the business of chicken rearing, and she also buys and sells Matemba (small dried fish) and clothing. She has been doing this business for the past four years now with the assistance of one employee.

She has requested $400 to buy 200 day-old chicks, 30 bags of chicken feeds, and chemicals. The challenge that Chipo faces is that of poultry death and chicken feed shortages.

She sees herself starting a piggery project in the coming five years as her chicken business grows and expands. She will use the profits to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy chicks, chicken feed, and chicken vaccines.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 47, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Angel is operating a service-based business providing transportation services to local community members. Angel has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month for these activities.

In 1994, Angel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angel is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which he will use to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more gold dust from the village and to buy items like canned goods, shampoos, and snacks to sell in the sari sari store.

loans.name: Richmei

texts.en:
Richmei is from the village of Centro napo Tudela. She is 25 years old and single. To make a living, Richmei owns and operates a transportation services business, which she has been doing for two years. She earns 9,800 PHP a month.

During a recent visit to her house, Richmei explains that her prior Kiva loan through Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative,  which she has repaid, allowed her to repair the engine of her motorcycle. 

Richmei is requesting her fourth loan for 20,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase a second-hand motorcycle for transportation. She decided to add another motorcycle to double her earnings.

In 2009, Richmei joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to buy a third motorcycle from her returns to triple her earnings.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Syrgaim

texts.ru:
Сыргаим  52 года, замужем и имеет пятерых взрослых детей. Сыргаим - активная,  трудолюбивая и жизнерадостная женщина, вкладывающая свою позитивную энергию и любовь в ручной пошив кыргызских национальных изделий. Ее красивые и изящные изделия пользуются большим спросом среди местного населения, и становятся частью приданого для местных невест.  
Также энергичная Сыргаим занимается животноводством – откормом и продажей скота.  Начав этот бизнес три года назад с начальной суммы в 3,000 сом (KGS), она сумела развить хозяйство, насчитывающее 4 барана и 2 коровы с ежемесячным доходом в 3,000 сом.    
  В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Сыргаим обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме  40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота.   В дальнейшем, она планирует увеличить свое  хозяйство и расширить бизнес.
texts.en: Syrgaim is 52 years old, married and has five adult children.  She is an active, hardworking and happy person, who invests her positive energy and love into hand-sowing Kyrgyz national items.  Her beautiful and elegant products are in high demand among the local residents and become included in dowries for local brides.  The energetic Syrgaim is also involved in animal husbandry - fattening up and selling livestock.  Having started this business three years ago with an initial sum of 3,000 som (KGS), she was able to grow her business to include four sheep and two cows and yield a monthly income of 3,000 som.  In order to further develop her business, Syrgaim requested a loan in the sum of 40,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase additional livestock.  In the future, she plans to grow her farm and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a resident of Murang'a in Central Kenya. He is 48 years old and married with 2 adult children. He has been farming for 20 years. His farm produces milk and tea, which go to the local market. For additional income, he also runs a retail cereal business at the market.

Stephen has made a loan request of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to enable the purchase of a motorcycle so he can venture into the transport business. He says the business will help him market his farm produce and increase his sales thereby  increasing his income in turn. He expects his high transportation costs to go down with the funding from Juhudi Kilimo.

He mentions that transportation is very costly for farm produce, so the motorcycle will help him with cheaper delivery of his produce to the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy four rolls of material and maize.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 21 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda. For the past year, Monica has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Monica has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetic  body lotions and will help Monica to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. Monica hopes that in the future she will be able to become a doctor. 

Monica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Monica's future prospects by helping her to improve her capital.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetic body lotions.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 25 years old and is married with one child.  Francoise owns a business selling women's clothes.  She has five years in this business and the hours of her work are from 8am until 7pm every day except on Sunday. 

Francoise has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more women's clothes to sell.  With any profits, she will be able to save for her future and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more women's clothes for resale.

loans.name: Merluville

texts.en:
Merluville is 25 years old and married with 2 children. She is from Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. 

Merluville operates a family member's business venture providing transportation services to local community members, and she's been in this business for 6 months. She earns 5,000PHP a month from this work.

Merluville joined GDMPC in 2009 to obtain financial services to improve her living situation. Merluville is requesting a loan of 10,000PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in her family's business. This will be the second loan taken out by Merluville from GDMPC. She plans to have her own house and lot someday.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in her family's business.

loans.name: Marie Sthéphanie

texts.fr:
Femme âgée de 43ans, mariée, mère de  4 enfants, avec son niveau 3em, elle se lance dans la restauration  en 2007.
Elle commence à 7 heures avec la cafète et à a partir de 10 heures, elle enchaine avec le restaurant ou elle propose des mets variés Son restaurant est situé en plein marché et sa clientèle est composée des passants et des vendeurs du dit marché.
Ses recettes journalières varient entre 40.000f et 60.000f.
Elle est cliente de Hope depuis le premier cycle et aujourd'hui elle est  avec le groupe pilote  solidaire. elle a été sélectionnée comme une cliente modèle qui a remboursée sans défauts de payement.
Avec ce nouveau  prêt, elle va renforcée son activité en achetant :
1panier de poisson fume, 1carton de poisson salé, 1sac de riz, 1bidon d’huile, 1filet de d’oignon, 1carton de boîtes de lait, 1 grosse boite de margarine, 1 grosse boite de café, 2 cartons de spaghetti, 12sacs de charbon de bois, ajouter des ustensiles telles  que assiettes, tasses et sous tasses, 3douzaines de cuillères à café, 5 douzaines de cuillerée à soupe ,5douzainesde fourchettes, 2couteaux de cuisines.
Elle épargne pour avoir un prêt plus important qui va lui permettre de réaliser ses rêves :
Ouvrir  un autre  restaurant plus moderne.
Aider au mieux ses enfants à terminer leurs études.
Les gens pensent que c’est une bonne femme qui apporte sa contribution dans son foyer.
texts.en:
This woman is 43 years old, married, and has 4 children. Having completed junior high school, she started a food preparation business in 2007.
She starts at 7AM with tea and coffee, and from 10AM onward goes to the restaurant where she prepares various dishes. Her restaurant is located in the open market and her customers comprise shoppers and merchants from the same market.
Her daily revenue varies from 40,000F to 60,000F.
She has been a client with Hope since the first loan cycle and she is currently with the pilot solidarity group. She was selected as a model client who has repaid her loans without defaulting.
With this new loan, she is going to strengthen her business by buying one basket of smoked fish, one box of salted fish, one bag of rice, one can of oil, one bag of onions, one box of canned milk, one large tin of margarine, one large tin of coffee, two boxes of spaghetti, 12 bags of charcoal, and utensils such as plates, cups, saucers, three dozen teaspoons, five dozen tablespoons, five dozen forks, and two kitchen knives.
She has been saving to obtain a more significant loan that will allow her to realize her dreams, which are to open another more modern restaurant and to help her children as much as possible in finishing their studies.
People's general opinion of her is that she is a good woman who does her part in providing for her household.

loans.use: To buy a box of salted fish, a basket of smoked fish, one can of oil, one bag of rice, one box of canned milk, one large tin of coffee, one large tine of margarine, two bags of charcoal, and restaurant materials.

loans.name: Danahon's Group

texts.en:
Danahon is the leader of his group. She is 54 years old and is married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she brings up two sons and a daughter. The older son works in Russia, the daughter is a farmer, and the youngest son goes to kindergarten. 

In 2000, with an initial investment of 8000 soms, Danahon purchased four sheep. Since that time she has been engaged in cattle breeding. At the moment, she keeps a cow and calf.  From selling the dairy products and reselling sheep after fattening them, Danahon earns about 5000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Danahon plans to purchase cattle for breeding. In the near future, she wants to prepare a wedding dowry for the daughter.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 30 years old and is married with two children. She owns a beauty salon business . She has had this business for one year and the hours of her work are from 8am until 11pm every day except on Saturday.  She currently employs one person to help her. 

Beatha has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her beauty salon business by purchasing more materials like chairs and helmets.  With any profits she will be able to save for her future, reinvest in her business and pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to expand her beauty salon business by purchasing more materials.

loans.name: Yuuya Shg Group

texts.en:
Rose is the facilitator of the Yuuya SHG group. Rose and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rose takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to eradicate poverty and to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had an excellent maize yield harvesting 15 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Rose was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Rose will educate her children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Yuuya SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Rose is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Chiratidzo

texts.en: This is 28 year old Chiratidzo from Chitungwiza, married with one child. He also cares for one dependent. Chiratidzo is into poultry business. The business has been in operation for 11 years. He says the main challenges faced are competition and the rate at which the chicks die. Chiratidzo has requested a loan of $600.00 to buy chicks and feed. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow him  to improve the standard of life of his family. In the future Chiratidzo plans to expand his business and sell more than 300 birds per month.

loans.use: To buy Chicks and Stock feeds

loans.name: Ngamilo Group

texts.en:
Stephen is the facilitator of the Ngamilo group. Stephen and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Stephen takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund for the quality farm produce and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Stephen had an excellent maize yield harvesting 23 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Stephen was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Stephen and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Stephen will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Ngamilo group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Stephen is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr:
Yao est un homme âgé de 29 ans. Il est célibataire. Il n’a pas d’enfants.  
Yao travaille comme revendeur depuis 2007. Il vend des accessoires d’électricité pour tous clients à domicile. Il achète les produits à Lomé. Il travaille seul. Au moment, il n’a aucune difficulté principale. 
Yao a requis son 1er  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter et vendre des accessoires d’électricité. Il veut agrandir l’étalage de son activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Yao voudrait ouvrir une boutique. Il dit qu’avec les profits, il prévoit de se marier et subvenir au besoin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Yao is a 29-year-old man. He is unmarried and has no children. He has been working as a retailer since 2007 and sells electrical accessories out of his home to any customer. He purchases the goods in Lomé, the capital of Togo. He works by himself. At the moment, he has no major difficulties. 

Yao has requested his first loan from WAGES to buy some electrical goods to sell. He wants to expand his display of goods. In the next few years, he would like to open a store. 

With the profits, he says he plans to get married and to support his family.

loans.use: to buy electrical accessories

loans.name: Liberatha

texts.en:
Liberatha is 32 years old and married with two children. She owns a business selling cows. Liberatha works from 6 am until 6 pm every day, and she currently employs one person to help her. This is her third successful year in the business.

Liberatha has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her animal sales business. She will save any additional profits so that in the future she can reinvest in her business and be able to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more cows for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy shoes and clothes for resale

loans.name: Extreme Group

texts.en:
Thadiwe is a 26 year old lady who is married and has 2 children aged 5 years and 6 months. Her husband is a footballer and he plays for Masvingo United FC. They do not have other dependants.

She sells clothes and is also a hair dresser. She operates from home and she has been in the business for 2 years. She does not have any employees. As a group they meet once a week to discuss issues affecting the members and the way forward. She however faces a challenge of high competition in the market and import duty that is charged on the goods that she buys. In the next 5 years she would like to open her own hair salon and boutique to operate from. With the profits she would be able to provide for a better future for her children

loans.use: to buy hair weaves, clothes and shoes

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is aged 53 and carries out farming in Murang'a Central Kenya. He has been in active farming for 20 years and currently employs two farmhands and produces milk and tea which he sells to the local market. He also runs a retail shop in the local market for additional income. He is married with 3 adult children.

James has made a loan request of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy pigs for a venture into pig farming business. He says his pig business will grow due to high costs of beef and the low number of farmers in the business. His focus is to run a sustainable farming business.

He laments of high costs of feeds but glad Juhudi Kilimo is offering much needed help.

loans.use: To buy pigs

loans.name: Hapizahon's Group

texts.en:
Hapizahon is the leader of this group. She is 43 and married to a constructor, who earns about 5000 soms per month. Together with her husband she brings up two sons and two daughters. The sons work in construction, the first daughter is a farmer and the youngest daughter studies at school. In 1993 with an initial investment of 4000 soms Hapizahon purchased a calf and since that time she breeds cattle. She always has feed for cattle, because she grows agricultural products such as: cabbage, corn and potatoes.  Selling the dairy products and some part of the harvest she earns additional 3000 soms to family budget. At the moment the family plans to celebrate the daughter’s wedding. Hapizahon applies for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to prepare a weeding dowry for her daughter.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to prepare a wedding dowry for the daughter

loans.name: Anamer

texts.en:
Anamer is 34 year old and single. She lives in Oroquieta City. 

Anamer has been 10 years in raising crops work, planting & harvesting rice for sale and she earn 40,000PHP a month with this work.

Anamer joined GDMPC in 2005 to gain financial services to help improve her living situation and to improve her ability to engage in business activities. Anamer is requesting a loan of 50,000PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Anamer from GDMPC. Anamer hopes to improve/expand her business to gain more income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mwangaza Group

texts.en:
Calistus is the facilitator of the Mwangaza group. His group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Calistus takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to have additional maize profits to send his children to school and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Calistus had an excellent maize yield harvesting 13 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Calistus was only able to harvest four bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Calistus and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Calistus will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Mwangaza group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Calistus is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Raina

texts.fr:
Raina est une femme âgée de 31 ans. Elle est mariée å un chauffeur. Elle a 2 enfants, dont 1 à l’école. Le premier a 10 ans et le dernier a 2 ans.  
Raina travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2007. Elle revend des pagnes, des chaussures et du charbon pour tout client de façon  ambulante. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, elle n’a aucune difficulté. 
Raina a requis son 1er  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes, des chaussures et du charbon. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Raina voudrait élargir son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit  s’occuper de sa famille.
texts.en:
Raina is a 31-year-old woman. She is married to a driver. She has two children, one of whom is in school. The elder is 10, the younger 2 years old. 

Raina has been working as a retailer since 2007. She walks around selling pagnes [traditional wraps], shoes and charcoal to all her customers. She buys her products in Lomé. She works alone. For now, she doesn't have any problems.

Raina requested this first loan with WAGES in order to buy pagnes, shoes and charcoal. She wants to reinvest in the business. 

In the coming years, Raina would like to grow her business. She says that with the profits, she intends to look after her family.

loans.use: to buy pagnes, shoes and bags of charcoal

loans.name: Bidii Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bidii Group in Western Kenya! Rose is the facilitator of the Bidii group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rose takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and because One Acre Fund has the best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had an excellent maize yield harvesting five bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rose was only able to harvest two bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Rose will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Bidii group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows nine people; six women and two men, plus the Field officer on the far left. The total number of members is nine but one is absent.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Léon

texts.fr:
Léon est un homme âgé de 36 ans. Il est célibataire. Il n’a pas enfants.  
Léon travaille comme revendeur depuis 2010. Il achète et vent des télés pour tous clients dans sa boutique. Il achète les produits à Lomé. Il travaille seul. Au moment, il n’a aucune difficulté. 
Léon a requis son 1er  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des télévisions et radios. Il veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Léon voudrait élargir l’activité. Il dit qu’avec les profits, il prévoit de prendre soin de sa future famille.
texts.en:
Léon is a 36-year-old man who is unmarried and has no children. He has been working as a retailer since 2010. He buys TV's and sells them to any customer in his store. He purchases the goods in Lomé, the capital of Togo. He works by himself. At the moment, he has no difficulties. 

Léon has requested his first loan with WAGES to buy TV's and radios. He wants to reinvest in his business. In the next few years, he would like to expand. 

With the profits, he says he plans on taking care of his future family.

loans.use: to buy televisions and radios

loans.name: Andalala Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Andalala Group in Western Kenya! Emanuel is the facilitator of the Andalala group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Emanuel takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizers and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Emanuel had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Emanuel was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Emanuel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Emanuel will save for the future and pay bank loans.

In 2012, the members of Andalala group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Emanuel and his group members appear in the photograph above. Standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Dong

texts.en: Dong is 49 years old. She lives in Nguyet Cau village, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She has three children. They are married. Mrs Dong sells fruit in the market. She has this job for ten years. She has a monthly income of about 5.000.000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2008. The last time she borrowed 8.288.000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. This is the 5th time she borrows money from SEDA. In this loan cycle she would like to borrow 9.184.000 VND to buy more fruits to sell with purpose to earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy more fruits to sell

loans.name: Nabeki Shg Group

texts.en:
Bonface is the facilitator of Nabeki Shg group. Bonface and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Bonface takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to learn good planting teachings and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Bonface had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Bonface was only able to harvest two bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Bonface and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Bonface will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Nabeki Shg group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Bonface is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Akoua est une femme âgée de 51 ans. Elle est mariée å un cuisinier. Elle a 2 enfants, dont 1 à l’école. Le premier a 30 ans et le dernier a 25 ans.  
Akoua travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2000. Elle est revendeuse d’alimentation générale pour tous clients dans sa boutique. Elle achète les produits au grand marché. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, elle n’a aucune difficulté. 
Akoua a requis son 2ème  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter et revendre de l’alimentation générale. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Akoua voudrait élargir son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de prendre soin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Akoua is a 51-year-old woman. Her husband is a cook. She has two children, one of whom attends school. Her older son is 30 years old, and her younger son is 25 years old. 

Akoua has been working as a retailer since 2000. She has a shop where she sells food products to the public. She buys the products at the Grand Market. She runs her business by herself. At the moment, she has no problems. 

Akoua has asked for a second loan through WAGES in order to buy and resell food products. She wants to reinvest in her business. In the coming years, Akoua would like to expand her business. She says that with the profits, she plans to care for her family.

loans.use: to buy food products

loans.name: Msamaria Nabeki Fab Group

texts.en:
Edwin is the facilitator of the Msamaria Nabeki FAB group. Edwin and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Edwin takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund for the quality planting training and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Edwin had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Edwin was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Edwin and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Edwin will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Msamaria Nabeki FAB group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Edwin is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Wanjoya Shg A Group

texts.en:
Alice is the facilitator of the Wanjoya SHG A group.  Alice and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Alice takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund for the best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alice was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Alice will educate her children, build a house and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Wanjoya SHG A group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Alice is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jacklyne

texts.en:
Jacklyne is a mother and a farmer in Kitale area of Western Kenya where she lives with her family of 7 children, all schooling save for the first born. She has been doing farming for 20 years running and currently produces maize and milk for the local market.

Jacklyne has decided to make a loan request with Juhudi amounting to 51,200 KES to enable her to boost her dairy farming by buying and insuring an additional cow at 31,200 KES and purchase poultry birds at 20,000 KES and venture into poultry farming as well.

She laments of high cost of feeds in the area especially during acute dry weather.She is advocating for an introduction of school fees loans by Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds and buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Wanjoya Shg E Group

texts.en:
Charles is the facilitator of the Wanjoya SHG E group. Charles and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Charles takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund for One Acre Fund’s best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Charles had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Charles was only able to harvest three bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Charles and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Charles will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Wanjoya SHG E group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Charles is pictured with his group members. The field officer is on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Terimbere/rhng Group

texts.fr:
Noel fait partie du groupe Terimbere/Rhng. Il a 24 ans et il est marié mais il n’a pas des enfants. Son niveau d’éducation est de 6  ans de primaire.

Noel est cultivateur des tomates. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture des tomates. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est agrandir la récolte des tomates en utilisant des engrais chimiques.  Dans les prochaines années il prévoit d'etre le grand fournisseur des tomates dans sa région . Avec les profits, Noel prévoit d’éduquer et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en:
Noel is a member of the Terimbere/Rhng group. He is 24 years old and married, but has no children. He received 6 years of primary school education. 

Noel is a tomato farmer. This is his first loan cycle with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy chemical fertilizers to help grow his tomatoes. 

His strategy for growing his business is to enlarge his tomato crop by using chemical fertilizers. In the coming years he hopes to become a large tomato supplier for his region. With the profits, Noel plans to educate and care for his children.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers to grow tomatoes

loans.name: Enjelesia Group

texts.en:
Amos is the facilitator of Enjelesia group. His group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Amos takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and quality maize production. In the recent 2011 season, Amos had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Amos was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Amos and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Amos will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Enjelesia group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Amos is pictured with his group members

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr:
Ayaba est une femme âgée de 24 ans. Elle est mariée å un commerçant. Elle a 2 enfants, dont 1 à l’école. Le premier a 5 ans et le dernier a 2 ans.  
Ayaba travaille comme coiffeuse depuis 2007. Elle achète et vend des mèches, des pagnes et des robes de marié pour tout client dans sa boutique. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seul. Au moment, n’a pas de difficulté. 
Ayaba a requis son 1er  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter et vendre des pagnes et des mèches. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Ayaba voudrait élargir l’activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de s’occuper de la famille.
texts.en: Ayaba is a 24-year-old woman. She is married to a storekeeper. She has two children, one of whom is in school. Her oldest is 5 years old and her youngest is two. Ayaba has been a hairdresser since 2007. She buys and sells hair extensions, pagnes [traditional wraps] and wedding dresses for all the clients in her boutique. She purchases supplies in Lomé. She works by herself. Presently, she does not have any problems. Ayaba asked for her 1st loan from WAGES for the purchase and sale of pagnes and hair extensions. She would like to reinvest in this business. In the coming years, Ayaba would like to grow the business. She says that she will take care of her family with the profits.

loans.use: to purchase pagnes [traditional wraps] and hair extensions.

loans.name: Nam

texts.en: Nam is 53 years old. She lives in Nguyet Cau village, Yen Phong Bac Ninh. She has 4 children. They are married. Mrs Nam has a restaurant. She sells rice and noodles, instant noodles. She works there with her husband's help. She has this job for 5 years. She has a monthly income of about 7.000.000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2008 and always pays loans punctually. This is 5th time she borrows a loan from SEDA. In this loan cycle she would like to borrow 9.184.000 VND to repair her restaurant.

loans.use: to repair her restaurant.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a water pump and pipes.

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin is 49 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 9 and 16 years old. Celestin has three years' experience selling use clothing in the market. He currently employs one person to help him and his business is open from 6 am to 6 pm each week except on Saturdays.

Celestin has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more used clothing to sell. With any profits, Celestin would like to satisfy his basic needs and start saving for his future and build a house for his family.

loans.use: to purchase more second hand to sell.

loans.name: Yuuya Shg A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Yuuya SHG A Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner, One Acre Fund, in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Maurine is the facilitator of this group. She takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access quality farm produce and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Maurine had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Maurine was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Maurine and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Maurine will educate her children and ensure food security.
In the photograph above, Maurine is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Marc

texts.en:
Marc is 32 years old and married with 4 children between the ages of 1 and 9. He owns a business selling various goods such as soap, toothpaste, eggs, and biscuits. He has 2 years' experience in this business. He works from 6 am until 11 pm every day, and he currently employs two people to help him. 

Marc has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional goods to sell. With any profits, he will be able to save and he will reinvest in his business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase various goods to sell.

loans.name: Imara Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Imara Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner, One Acre Fund, in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Hellen is the facilitator of the Imara Group. She takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Hellen had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Hellen was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Hellen and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Hellen will educate her children and ensure food security.
In the photograph above, Hellen is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has been a farmer in Nkubu, central Kenya, for twelve years and produces cabbages and carrots for the local market. She is married and has three children, a set of twins aged 16, and a third, aged 13. They are all in school.

Mary has requested a loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds and venture into poultry farming. She says the loan will help boost her farming income and educate her children. She also plans to buy more land to get more acreage and continue with her farming expansion.

Mary notes that crop diseases are rampant and much is spent in managing the diseases. She is, however, happy with the good relationship Juhudi Kilimo staff have with farmers.

loans.use: to purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single.
 
He has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. He has had this business for ten years. He requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Vicente has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, he hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Fanya Kazi Group

texts.en:
Alice is the facilitator of the Fanya Kazi group. Her group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Alice takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to eradicate poverty and in order to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 22 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Alice was only able to harvest 12 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children and ensure food security
In 2012, the members of Fanya Kazi group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Alice is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more soap, soft drinks, and tissue for her business.

loans.name: Evie

texts.en:
Evie is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has three children.
 
Evie is providing motorela or habal-habal services. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy tools and pay for gasoline and maintenance.

Evie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Evie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline and maintenance.

loans.name: Mounira

texts.en:
Mounira is a 29-year-old single woman who is working hard to prove herself to her friends and relatives. She is an industrious woman who improves her business as much as she can by adding new products attractive to new customers. 

Her nine years of experience in the field of mixing and creating special perfume blends has earned her the trust of her customers and given her encouragement to continue mixing new scents in the future.  In response to her customers' needs and requests, Mounira will put a great deal of effort into improving and expanding her perfume-making sector.

Mounira has also started selling hookah, which is a highly requested item these days and brings a good income.

This is Mounira's second cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower. Her previous loan helped a great deal to improve her hookah business; at this time, she is requesting a loan from this Kiva partner in order to buy new perfume collections, in addition to special bottles. She also hopes to open a private perfume atelier, where she can make her special blends and expand her market.

loans.use: To increase her selection of perfumes with new collections and bottles

loans.name: Menu Farmers Shg Group

texts.en:
Wycliff is the facilitator of the Menu Farmers SHG group. His group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Wycliff takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Wycliff had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, he was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wycliff and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Wycliff will invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Menu Farmers SHG group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Wycliff is pictured with his group members. The field officer appears in the far left of the photograph.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 25 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 

Joy has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 3 years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Joy has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Joy hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Laurent

texts.en:
Laurent has 6 children aged 1 to 13. He has been a maize farmer for 23 years. He would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production.
 
With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop

loans.name: Rotchelyn

texts.en:
Rotchelyn is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 

Rotchelyn has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 8 years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Rotchelyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Rotchelyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Monique

texts.en:
Monique is 30 years old and married with one child who is three years old. She owns a business selling various goods such as cosmetics and handicrafts. Monique has been in the business for three years. Her hours are 7 am to 6 pm, and she currently employs one person to help her. 

Monique has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products to sell. With any profits from the loan, Monique will save for her future, and she hopes to buy her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics and handicrafts to sell.

loans.name: Welfrida

texts.en:
Welfrida is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 

Welfrida has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 9 years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Welfrida has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Welfrida hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Sawsan

texts.en: Sawsan is a 36-year-old married woman, mother of three children, who worked hard to help her husband in raising them. She is a very hardworking woman. She started her small business selling shoes and clothes in 2011 and is improving it as much as she can to help her family's living. Sawsan  has improved her business through four loan cycles with Kiva partner Al Majmoua. She Is a borrower in good standing. With the requested loan, Sawsan will increase her autumn-winter collection to provide her customers with a variety of clothes that are suitable for the present and coming seasons. She hopes to expand her business more and more and to open a new shop with very attractive decoration, and with new quality of products and new customers.

loans.use: To increase her autumn/winter clothing collection

loans.name: Massah

texts.en: Masrah is 48 years old and lives in Paynesville, Liberia. She is married and has nine children aged between 9 and 29 years old who all attend school and live at home. For the past twenty years she has been selling charcoal in her community and now she is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. Her main challenges are transporting her goods and the rainy season. Masrah says she started her business with money given to her by her husband and she learned the business from her mother. What she really likes about her business is that it helps her to meet her needs and always have some money. She hope to build a house for her children in future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Lyudmila

texts.ru:
Людмиле 60 лет, она живет ж городе Иджеване (Ijevan). Людмила замужем и у нее трое детей: два сына и дочь. Дочь и старший сын со своими семьями проживают отдельно, а младший сын со своей семьей живет вместе с родителями. Муж Людмилы пенсионер. 
 С 1990 года Людмила вместе с мужем занимается сельским хозяйством. Совместными усилиями они разводят коров, свиней и кур. Также они выращивают овощи и фрукты. Вся полученная сельскохозяйственная продукция используется в семье. 
Для увеличения доходов семьи, Людмила вместе с мужем хочет начать выращивать корольки и инжир на продажу. Людмиле необходим кредит на сумму 1.000.000 драм для ограждения для своего сада, а также для покупки саженцев королька и инжира. 
Данный кредит является 4-ым по счету, получаемым Людмилой от организации Нор Оризон. Людмила некогда не имела просрочек при выплате кредита.
texts.en: Lyudmila is 60 years old.  She lives in the town of Ijevan.  She is married and has three children: two sons and a daughter.  The daughter and oldest son live with their families and separately from Lyudmila, and the youngest son and his family live with the parents.  Lyudmila's husband is a retiree.  She and her husband have been involved in agriculture since 1990.  With their joint efforts, they breed cattle, pigs and chickens.  They also grow vegetables and fruits.  All of the received agricultural products are used in the family.  In order to increase the family's income, Lyudmila and her husband want to start growing oranges and figs for sale.  Lyudmila needs a loan in the sum of 1,000,000 dram for fencing in her garden and purchasing orange and fig seedlings.  This loan is Lyudmila's fourth from the Nor Horizon organization.  She has never been late repaying her loans.

loans.use: to fence in her garden and buy seedlings

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. Elizabeth provides motorcycle or "habal-habal" services with her husband as the driver. She has had this business for 6 years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy tools and pay for gasoline. Elizabeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en: Cerina is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. Cerina has a shop that sells canned goods, coffee powder, noodles & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more inventory. Cerina has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, coffee & chocolate powder, & beverages

loans.name: Bukiabi Poultry Farmers A Group

texts.en:
David is the facilitator of the Bukiabi Poultry Farmers A group. His group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. As with the majority of people in Western Kenya, the members of this group are farmers who rely on maize for yearly food security and income.
David takes care of ten children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, he had an excellent maize yield harvesting 19 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  David was only able to harvest 9 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to David and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, David will educate his children and build a house. In 2012, the members of Bukiabi Poultry Farmers A group will each plant maize on plots between half and 1 acre.
In the photograph, David is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 6 children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren). Imelda has a restaurant business. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Imelda sells her products from home. Imelda has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, bags of rice, chicken, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes, and cassava.  She also generates additional income through selling piped water and renting rooms. The main business challenge(s) for Imelda include transportation, defaulters, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully-stocked restaurant. Imelda lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and buying medication.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas, bags of rice, chicken, beef, and sweet and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 

Ester has a shop that sells dried fish, spices, eggs, and sugar. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy dried fish and spices to sell.

Ester has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Ester hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy dried fish and spices to sell

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 38-year-old married man and is an owner of a grocery store. Hassan is a hard worker; he improves his living and his business. Through four loan cycles from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, he has been a good standing borrower and at the same time, they reflected positively on his social and financial situations.

Hassan is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to start a new trade that will increase his income through selling mobile prepaid cards, which are highly requested in his area. 

Hassan will also start distributing bread early in the morning to make sure that his family's needs are met. Hassan hopes to keep on expanding his business as much as he can through introducing new products to his customers.

loans.use: to start selling prepaid mobile cards

loans.name: Amba B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Amba B Group in Western Kenya! Phylis is the facilitator of the Amba B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Phylis takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to have quality maize seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Phylis had an excellent maize yield harvesting 22 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Phylis was only able to harvest five bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Phylis and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Phylis will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing. 

Phylis is pictured with her group members in the above photograph.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 

Anabel has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Anabel has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Anabel hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina is 32 years old and lives in the Paynesville suburb of Monrovia, Liberia. She is married and has two children, aged two and 12. One attends school, and both live at home. 

For the past twenty years, Tina has been selling soap, tissue, and sugar. She is requesting a loan to purchase more of these goods for her business. Her main challenge is that she has fewer goods on her table to sell. 

Tina says she started this business with goods given to her by her sister and learned it from her. She likes her business because it helps her to send her children to school. She hopes to build a house for her children in future.

loans.use: To purchase more soap, tissue, and sugar for her business

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. She has a shop where she sells fish like milk fish, sardines & mackerel. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 14,000 to buy more fish to sell.

Amelia has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Shafkat

texts.ru: Шафкат уже четыре года занимается скотоводством. Он разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Ему 37 лет. Он женат. У него трое детей. Шафкат берет кредит для закупа коровы и телят.
texts.en: Shafkat has been in animal farming for four years. He raises cattle for later resale. He is 37 years old. He is married, with three children. Shafkat is taking out a loan in order to buy a cow and some calves.

loans.use: to buy a cow and some calves

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 6 children. She has a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 3 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 13,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell.

Marilyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy electronic loads for mobile phones

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy  lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 6 children, all of her children go to school.  She has two additional family members. 

Prossy sells fast foods in a restaurant on a retail basis. She has been in business for the last 15 years.  She also teaches at a primary school where she gets her other source of income.  She works seven days a week. 

Prossy has requested a loan of 600000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of Irish potatoes, beef and sausages. Her major business challenges are: the ever increasing prices of foodstuff in Uganda, the holidays because many of her customers are university students, transportation, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to own a fully-stocked a restaurant so as to serve more customers. 

Prossy lives in a rented house and her family does not have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expense is school fees and rent

loans.use: buy potatoes, beef and sausages

loans.name: Paterna

texts.en:
Paterna is 61 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. She has a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 7 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 12,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell.

Paterna has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Adelaida is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has one child. Adelaida has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 15 years. She requested a loan for 12,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages. Adelaida has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Adelaida hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Kimasi A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Kimasi A Group in Western Kenya! Maximilla is the facilitator of the Kimasi A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Maximilla takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Maximilla had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Maximilla was only able to harvest four and a half bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Maximilla and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Maximilla will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Kimasi A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured with her group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 

Salome has a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. Salome requested a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has been a member of HSPFI since 2011 and hopes to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Sango A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sango A Group in Western Kenya! Everlyne is the facilitator of the Sango A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Everlyne takes care of 14 children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Everlyne had an excellent maize yield harvesting four bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Everlyne was only able to harvest one bag of maize on that land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Everlyne and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Everlyne will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Sango A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

The photograph shows nine people; six women and three men, with the field officer on the far left. The total number of members is 10 but two are absent.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is 57 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 

Nida has a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. Nida requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Nida has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Nida hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Imara A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Imara A Group in Western Kenya! Josephine is the facilitator of the Imara A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Josephine is a mother of three children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Josephine had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Josephine was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land.
