With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Josephine and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Josephine will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Imara A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.ru: Шавкат проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Ему 44 года. Он женат. У него четверо детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам Шавкат занимается торговлей. У него имеется собственный магазин, где он продает детскую одежду. Этим видом бизнеса занимается восемь лет. Кредит берет для приобретения новых видов костюмчиков.
texts.en: Shakvat lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 44 years old, married and has four children. His wife stays at home and Shakvat is in retail. He has been managing a children clothing store for the last eight years. He is requesting this loan to purchase a new batch of children outfits for the winter season.

loans.use: to purchase new kids of outfits

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth, a 34-year-old married mother of one child, lives in the Philippines where she has had a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages for five years. A member of HSPFI since 2011, she is requesting a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy more goods for her shop. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna, a 29-year-old married mother of two children, lives in the Philippines where she has had a shop that sells detergents, soaps and noodles for the past five years. A member of HSPFI since 2011, she has equested a loan for PHP 8,000 to more goods for her shop. In the future, Lorna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy detergents, soaps and noodles.

loans.name: Gueswendbala Tib Songdo Group

texts.fr:
Mme Pauline représente le groupe GUESWENDBALA TIB SONGDO. Mariée, elle est mère de 5 enfants. Le plus âgé a 17ans et le moins âgé a 1an.4 vont à l’école et elle a 2 personnes a sa charge.

Elle vend du savon liquide  et parfum depuis  4ans et parallèlement des condiments. Mme s’approvisionne au marché de paglayiri en ville. Ses clients sont les hommes et les femmes.

Elle veut s’acheter 5kg de poudre de savon, 2kg de colorant, une douzaine de parfum et un sac d’oignon.

Avec ses bénéfices, elle prend soin de ses enfants. Mme ambitionne agrandir son activité et s’occuper de l’avenir de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Pauline represents the group GUESWENDBALA TIB SONGDO. She is a married mother of five. The oldest is 17 years old and the youngest is one. Four of them go to school and and she is responsible for supporting two people.

For the last 4 years, she has been selling liquid soap and perfume, as well as condiments. Pauline gets her supplies at the Paglayiri market in town. She has both male and female customers.

She would like to buy 5kg of powdered soap, 2kg of colorant, a dozen perfumes and a bag of onions.

With her profits she takes care of her children. Pauline would like to grow her business and provide for the future of her children.

loans.use: to buy 5kg of soap powder, 2kg of colorant, a dozen perfumes, and a sack of onions

loans.name: Tigran

texts.ru:
Тиграну 25 лет, он проживает в городе Ванадзоре вместе со своими родителями, женой и 8-ми месячным сыном. Отец Тиграна работает заправщиком на газовой заправочной станции, мать – безработная, жена ухаживает за сыном. 
Четыре года назад Тигран переоборудовал свою комнату в квартире в мастерскую, где он изготавливает изделия из дерева. Он вырезает рамки из дерева для зеркал и картин, изготавливает сувениры, которые он сдает в магазины торгующие сувенирами. Тигран также принимает частные заказы на изготовление небольших разнообразных изделий из дерева. Благодаря своему бизнесу Тигран помогает отцу содержать семью и сейчас ему необходим на сумму 110.000 драм для приобретения материалов для своего бизнеса: дерева, лака и т.д.
texts.en: Tigran is 25 years old, he live in the city of Vanadzor together with his parents, his wife and their eight month old son. Tigran's father is a gas station attendant, his mother is unemployed and his wife is taking care of their baby. Four years ago Tigran has converted his apartment to a wood working studio. He carves frames for mirrors and paintings, makes souvenirs which he sells to a local souvenir store. Tigran also takes private orders to make small carved wooden items. Thanks to his woodworking business Tigran helps his father to support the family and he is requesting this loan of 110,000 dram to purchase raw materials for his trade: wood and lacquer.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for his business: wood, lacquer etc.

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar, a 50-year-old married father of two children, works hard for the sake of his family, operating more than one business at a time. Omar has worked in the construction field since 1980, selling stone rocks that are highly valued in his business for the exterior beauty they provide buildings. He also works in agriculture, planting and selling apples and kidney beans.  He has also started a bread business. 

A borrower in good standing, Omar is now requesting his second loan from Al Majmoua, his first one having enhanced his social and financial situation. The loan will be invested to improve his bread business, through buying big quantities and selling them in a wider region. Omar hopes to keep on expanding his businesses in order to continue raising his children in a healthy and educated environment.

loans.use: To improve his new bread business, through buying big quantities and selling them in a wider region.

loans.name: Njete Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Njete SHG Group in Western Kenya! Catherine is the facilitator of the Njete SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Catherine takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Catherine had an excellent maize yield harvesting 17 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Catherine was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Catherine and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Catherine will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Njete SHG group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured with her group members in the photograph above.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a resident of Nkubu, Central Kenya, where she has been farming for 10 years with the help of one farmhand. She is 51 and married with 3 children who are all adults. The youngest is still enrolled in post-secondary education. Her farm currently produces milk, spinach, potatoes, and tea for the local community.

Jane has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says this loan will help improve her farming income and enable her meet her family needs more easily. She is optimistic that her business will grow, and she plans to venture into the transport business, too.

She says that Juhudi Kilimo services are prompt, and she is glad to be in business with Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Godlove

texts.en:
Godlove is 27 years old. He is single and has no children. Ill health, poverty, the death of his sister, and the paralysis of his father’s arm are the major challenges he has faced in life. Godlove lives in Njibujang Bafut in the Mezam Division of the North West Region of Cameroon.

He joined GHAPE in 2007 and has received and successfully repaid Empowerment Credit loans three times. He invested his past loans in his general store and used the profit to feed, clothe, and provide medication for himself. He also reinvested part of the profit in his business. 

Given a loan, he will expand his general store and also buy a raffia bush. He thinks that this business will be a success because he already has so many customers who buy provisions of his general store. His business will be a great help to the community in that people will not have to go far in order to purchase items for their daily needs.

With the proceeds from this loan, he will improve upon his house and also get married. He prefers a GHAPE loan because he likes the installment method of repayment and also because the interest rates are lower.

loans.use: to buy provisions for his general store and also to buy a raffia bush.

loans.name: Dorris

texts.en: Dorris is 29 years old and lives in Paynesville South, Liberia. She lives with her partner and has two children, aged 3 and 7, who are in school and live at home. For the past seven years she has been selling slippers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers for her business. Dorris says she started this business with money given to her by her husband, and she learned this business from her mother. What she really likes about her business is that it helps her to have some money for herself. She hopes to become an international business woman in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers for her business.

loans.name: Baowendpinda Group

texts.fr:
Mme Sanata est la responsable du groupe BAOWENDPINDA. Elle a levé la main sur la photo.  Elle est marié et mère d’un enfant. Il a 12ans et va à l’école. Elle a une personne à sa charge.

Mme est tisseuse depuis 5ans et vend parallèlement des mangues à la période des mangues. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de kouritenga.Ses clients les hommes et femmes.

Elle veut s’acheter une  balle de fils de tisse et 03kg de teinture.

Avec ses bénéfices, elle économise et subvient à ses petits besoins. Elle ambitionne ouvrir une grande boutique de pagnes tissés et prendre soin de son enfant  pour un meilleur avenir.
texts.en:
Sanata is the leader of the Baowendpinda group. She has her hand raised in the photo. She is married and the mother of one boy, who is 12 and goes to school. She has one dependent. 

Sanata has been a weaver for the past 5 years, and also sells mangoes when they are in season. She obtains her supplies at the Kouritenga market, and her customers are male and female. Sanata wants to buy a bale of thread for weaving, and 03kg of dye. 

With her profits, she adds to her savings and and covers her basic needs. She plans to open a large shop of woven cloth (pagnes) and to take care of her child to give him a better future.

loans.use: to buy one bale of thread for weaving and 03kg of dye

loans.name: Sibumba C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sibumba C Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Ann is the facilitator of the Sibumba C Group. Ann takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to have a bigger harvest and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Ann had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Ann was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ann and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Ann will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.
In the photograph, Ann is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a ball of yarn and a ½ kg of dyes of various colors

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (two sisters). Madina lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees. Madina has a retail business. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days a week. She also generates additional income through welding.

Madina has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil for her shop. The main business challenges for Madina include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to buy a delivery van to ease transportation.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has five children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of her father. Betty has a business selling second hand clothes. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days a week. She also generates additional income through rental houses. Betty lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.  

Betty has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of used clothes.The main business challenges for Betty include transportation, ever increasing prices of used clothes, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to buy a delivery van to ease transportation.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a steel bender. Abena has been a small-scale trader at Kokoado in Elmina, Ghana for five years. She uses her income to assist her husband in educating their children. Abena will use the loan to purchase slippers for sale. With the new profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase slippers for sale.

loans.name: Simana B Group

texts.en:
Michael is the facilitator of the Simana B group. His group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Michael takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to have quality farm produce and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Michael had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Michael was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Michael and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Michael will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Simana B group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Michael is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is 58 years old and has been actively farming in his home area of Nkubu, Central Kenya for over 30 years. His farm produces potatoes, cabbages, tea, and milk for the local market. He sells cereals at the local market for additional income.

Stanley has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to build a zero grazing unit for his dairy cows. He says the construction will protect the feed for his animals and generate more income through improved production. He also expects major changes in his family's living standards.

He appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's services and is looking forward to a long term relationship with them.

loans.use: to construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 16 years. He is 51 years old, and he and his wife Margaret have four children who are all going to school.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of their existing clients and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

In future, Joshua hopes to become one of the leading farmers in Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Umoja A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Umoja A Group in Western Kenya! This  group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Cleophas is the facilitator of the Umoja A Group. She takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Cleophas had an excellent maize yield harvesting 8 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Cleophas was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Cleophas and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. With income from maize sales, Cleophas will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Umoja A Group will each plant plots between half and 1 acre of maize.
The photograph shows eight group members (one is absent), with the facilitator on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yuuya Shg A Group

texts.en:
Maurine is the facilitator of the Yuuya SHG A group. Maurine and her group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Maurine takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Maurine had a good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on three-quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Maurine was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on three-quarters of an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Maurine and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Maurine will educate her children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Yuuya SHG A group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
Maurine is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lukiya

texts.en:
Lukiya lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has five children, two of whom are in school. Lukiya has a business selling second hand clothes door-to-door. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days a week. Lukiya lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding her family and school fees.   

Lukiya has requested a loan of 1,300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of used clothes. The main business challenges for Lukiya include transportation, ever increasing prices of used clothes, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to buy a delivery van to ease transportation.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 46 years old and lives in Paynesville South, Liberia. She is a widow and has four children, ages 14 to 29. They are in school and live at home. For the past twenty years she has been selling rice and bread.

Martha is requesting a loan to purchase more rice and bread for her business. She says her main challenge is the location of her business. She started her business with a little money she received from her daughter, and she learned this business from her mother. She really likes her business because it helps her to support her children. She hopes to become an international businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and bread for her business.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through middle school. Ekua has sold cloth at Kokoado in Elmina, Ghana for eight years. Her husband is a driver. Ekua uses her income to assist her husband in raising their children. Ekua will use the loan to purchase cloth and materials for sale. With the new profits, Ekua plans to expand her business .

loans.use: to purchase cloth and materials for sale.

loans.name: Alaisha

texts.en:
Alaisha  lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has four children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of her brother and sister.  Alaisha operates a retail shop. She has been in this business for two months, and she works 7 days a week. Alaisha sells her products at the market. She also generates additional income through rental houses. She lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding her family and school fees.    

Alaisha has requested for a loan of 900,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sugar, salt, soap, rice, and maize flour.      The main business challenges for Alaisha include transportation, ever increasing prices of commodities, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to buy a delivery van to ease transportation.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, soap, rice, and maize flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish for sale.

loans.name: Kontye

texts.en:
Kontye used her first loan to buy sheep and goats for rearing and selling. She succeeded in selling them, and it was very profitable.
She repaid the loan well and in good time. She plans to use this loan to buy more sheep and goats, as well as cattle, for rearing and selling.

In the future, Kontye hopes to sell livestock to huge, renowned commercial slaughter houses in Nairobi and increase her income.

loans.use: to buy sheep and goats to rear and then sell.

loans.name: Awad

texts.en:
Awad is a 45-year-old married man and father of five children. Awad is a hard worker; he built a small cottage years ago to provide his family with their daily food for their living. Awad makes and sells specially made noodles, lupines, and corn. This kind of food is highly attractive to children in his region, especially during the evening and while celebrating holy occasions.

Awad has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to increase his food business by buying a large quantity of noodles at a discount. Awad also works in construction, specializing in cement work. Since this business is not going well, Awad is hoping to improve it also by buying new construction tools.

His food business is his main source of income. Through its income he covers his family's necessities. He hopes to provide his family with the best education and living, and hopes to improve his both of businesses as much as he can.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of noodles for his food selling business.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface has operated his tailoring shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last three years. He is 35 years old, and he and his wife Elizabeth have two children attending school.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of their existing clients, and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan to buy more material for use in his  tailoring shop.

In the future, Boniface hopes to expand his business, open many branches, and even offer tailoring training courses to other youths in the Ndunyu Njeru area, thereby increasing his income and improving his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more material for tailoring.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 25 years. She is 47 years old, and she and her husband Samuel have four children attending school. 

Mercy was introduced to KADET LTD by one of their existing clients, and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

In the future, Mercy hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Neh Isabella

texts.en:
Neh Isabella is single and has four children, all over the age of 15. She lives in a five-bedroom apartment with her children at Ntamulung, Mezam in the  Northwest region of Cameroon. The death of her brother and mother are the major challenges she has faced in her life. Poverty and the unemployment problem facing her children also continue to make her unhappy.

Neh Isabella joined GHAPE in 2006 and has taken and repaid Empowerment Credit loans several times. She used the profit from her past loans to feed, clothe, provide medication for, and educate her children. Given a loan, she intends to invest it in poultry farming. She believes that this business will be a success because she has many years of experience farming poultry and also because there is high demand for poultry products. Neh Isabella thinks that this activity will help her community in that it will provide manure to farmers in her locality, it will provide employment, and also because it will increase the supply of chicken in the market, which will improve people’s eating habits.

With the proceeds from her loan, she will provide for her children and also increase her capital. She prefers a GHAPE loan because of the easy method of repayment, low interest rates, and also because of the regular education and training GHAPE provides to its members.

loans.use: to purchase fowl, buy feed, and pay laborers.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina has been a small-scale trader selling food supplies at Kokoado in Elmina, Ghana for the past 6 years. She is married and has 3 children. She is responsible for assisting her husband to educate their children. Her loan will be used to buy more food supplies for sale. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy groceries for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a farmer in Nkubu.  Her farm produces beans, maize and milk, which all go to the local market.  She has been in farming for 20 years.  She is 38 years old, married, and has three children who are all in school.  She also sells cereals at the local market.  The cereals are sourced from her farm and from other farmers in the area.

Mary has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a bull cart. This is her second loan request through Juhudi, after repaying the first loan of 20,000 KES promptly.  She says the loan will help boost her farming income, since she will be able to transport her produce from the farm to her stores before taking the supplies to the market.  She adds that much of her income is lost when transporters are engaged during harvest to bring the produce to the market.

Mary states that lack of animal feed has made dairy farming difficult.

loans.use: buy a bull cart

loans.name: Kamkata S.h.g Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kamkata Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Getrude is the facilitator of the Kamkata SHG group. She takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Getrude had an excellent maize yield harvesting 14 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Getrude was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Getrude and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Getrude will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Kamkata SHG group will each plant between half and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: to source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Bidii A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bidii A Group in Western Kenya! Timothy is the facilitator of the Bidii A group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Timothy takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Timothy had a very good maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Timothy was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Timothy and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Timothy will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Bidii A group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Timothy is pictured with his group members in the photograph as shown.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth has operated her retail shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  She is 41 years old, married to James and they have five school-going children.  Apart from operating the retail shop as her primary activity, she also sells clothes to sustain her income.

Beth was introduced to KADET  LTD by one of our existing clients and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy more stock like sweets, cooking fat, rice,and washing detergent to sell in her retail shop.

In the future, Beth hopes to grow her retail shop to wholesale.

loans.use: buy more variety of stocks like sweets, cooking fat, rice,and washing detergent

loans.name: Mathilda

texts.en: Mathilda is single and has 2 children.  She is a baker at Kokoado in Elmina, which she has done for 5 years. Mathilda uses her income to pay for her children's school fees.  Mathilda will use the loan to purchase flour, sugar and cooking oil. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mathilda plans to educate her children through to the college level.

loans.use: buy flour, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Lena

texts.ru:
Лене 62 года. Она живет в Ванадзоре со своим мужем, который работает на заводе. Обе дочери Лены замужем и живут отдельно от родителей. 
Более 15 лет Лена занимается частным бизнесом: продажей женской одежды и белья. Лена арендует помещение на Ванадзорской центральной ярмарке, а товары она приобретает на Ереванских оптовых рынках. Лене очень нравиться заниматься бизнесом и помогать мужу содержать семью. У Лены много постоянных клиентов и поэтому ее товар раскупается очень быстро. 
Лена получала кредит от Нор Оризона 4 раза и сейчас ей необходим кредит на сумму 500.000 драм для приобретения зимнего ассортимента женской одежды и белья для своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Lena is 62 years old. She lives in Vanadzor with her husband who works at the factory. Both of Lena's daughters are married and live separately form their parents. For more then 15 years Lena has been in sales: she sells women's clothes and undergarments. Lena rents a store at the Vandzor central market and purchases her wares wholesale in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia. Lena likes managing her store and being able to help her husband support the family. She has many regular clients and her goods sell out quickly. 

Lena has taken a loan from Nor Horizon four times already and now she requested a loan of 500,000 dram to purchase a batch of winter clothes and undergarments for her store.

loans.use: To buy winter assortment of clothes and underclothes for her business

loans.name: Pastors Fellowship Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Pastors Fellowship Group in Western Kenya! Maurice is the facilitator of the group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Maurice takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Maurice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Maurice was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Maurice and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Maurice will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Pastors Fellowship group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Maurice is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

texts.en:

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last two years.  He is 26 years old, married to Penina and they have one child.  

Peter was introduced to KADET by one of our existing clients and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy farm inputs.

In the future, Peter hopes to expand his farming business and get more income, thereby improving his family's living.

loans.use: buy farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy farm inputs

loans.name: Eloy

texts.es: El señor Eloy es empleado en una empresa fabricadora de cera ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto. El crédito lo requiere para la refacción de su casa ya que hay filtraciones en los muros. Vive en casa de sus padres ubicada en la zona Llojeta  de la ciudad de La Paz es casado y tiene un hijo. El  cliente se encuentra muy contento con los créditos que se le otorgaron anteriormente y esta es la segunda vez que su crédito será canalizado a través de Kiva.
texts.en:
Sr. Eloy is employed at a wax factory in the city of El Alto. The loan he is requesting will be used to renovate his home since the walls are leaking. He lives at his parents’ house in the District of Llojeta in the city of La Paz. Eloy is married and has one child.

He is very pleased with the loans he received previously. This is the second time that his loan request is being referred to Kiva.

loans.use: to repair the walls of his house.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 29 years old and live in Paynesville.  She lives together with her partner and has two children, aged 2 and 9.  One of the children attends school and two of them stay at home. 

For the past six years, Martha has been selling plantains in the local market.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more plantains for her business. Martha says she started this business with money given to her by her sister and she learned this business from her.  She really likes her business because it provides for her needs.  She plans to buy a piece of land and build a house.

loans.use: buy plantains

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan has operated her bookbinding business and bookshop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last eight years.  She is 24 years old and single.

Susan was introduced to KADET by one of our existing clients and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy more stocks of books to sell in her bookshop, and also buy binding materials.

In the future, Susan hopes to expand her bookshop business and be able to distribute stationery material to both primary and secondary schools in Ndunyu Njeru.

loans.use: buy books and bookbinding materials

loans.name: Yibonelakho C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Yibonelakho C Group in Western Kenya! Collins is the facilitator of the Yibonelakho C group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Collins is a father of one child. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Collins had a good maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Collins was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Collins and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Collins will educate his child and invest in his business.

In 2012, the members of Yibonelakho C group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Collins is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: El señor Ricardo trabaja como  cerrajero. El crédito lo requiere para el techado y obra fina de una habitación en su casa para dar mayor comodidad a sus hijos. Vive en casa propia ubicada en la zona de Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz; Ricardo es viudo y tiene tres hijos. El  cliente se encuentra muy contento con los créditos que se le otorgaron ya que pudo mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia, pues esta es la quinta vez que Impro le concede un crédito y la segunda vez que se canaliza por Kiva.
texts.en:
Sr. Ricardo works as a locksmith. The loan he is requesting will be used to install a roof and finish a room in his house so that his children will be more comfortable. He lives in his own home in the District of Llojeta in the city of La Paz. Ricardo is a widower and has three children.

He is very pleased with the loans that have been provided so that he can improve his family’s living conditions. This is the fifth time that IMPRO has granted him a loan and the second time that it will be funded through Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase materials in order to install a roof and finish a room in his house.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en: Jenifer has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 20 years.  She is 55 years old and married to James. They have two school-going children. She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our existing clients and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings and also for labor purposes. In the future, Jenifer hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Ushindi Group in Western Kenya! Celestine is the facilitator of Ushindi group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Celestine takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Celestine had a very good maize yield, harvesting 13 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Celestine was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Celestine and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Celestine will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Ushindi group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: El señor Luís es rentista jubilado del sector militar. El crédito lo requiere para la refacción de pisos en su garaje, pues con el tiempo se ha desgastado completamente. Vive en casa propia ubicada en la zona Alto Sopocachi de la ciudad de La Paz; es viudo y tiene tres hijos. Esta es la primera vez que solicita un crédito, pero sus ingresos le permiten fácilmente efectuar los pagos mensuales.
texts.en:
Sr. Luís is a retired military pensioner. The loan he is requesting will be used to refurbish the floor of his garage which has completely worn out over time. He lives in his own home in the District of Alto Sopacachi in the city of La Paz. Luís is a widower and has three children.

This is the first time he has requested a loan. His income enables him to easily make the monthly payments.

loans.use: to refurbish the floor of his garage.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and a heifer

loans.name: Chui Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chui Group in Western Kenya! Philip is the facilitator of the Chui group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Philip takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. loans.name: Nabuloli Adult Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Nabuloli Adult Group in Western Kenya! Everlyne is the facilitator of the Nabuloli Adult group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Everlyne takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to improve her agricultural skills and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Everlyne had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 15 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Everlyne was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Everlyne and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Everlyne will repair her house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Nabuloli Adult group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Everlyne is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married with 6 children aged 6 to 18. He has been a maize farmer for 15 years. He would like a loan to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production: he needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With the profits from farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

loans.name: Marie Jeannine

texts.en:
Marie is married with 3 children aged between 3 and 16 years. She has been a maize farmer for 25 years. She would like the loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow her crop.

She will use the Kiva loan to cover labor costs and fertilizer costs during maize production. They need to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production.

With the profits from her farming, she wishes to reinvest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides.

loans.name: Sargis

texts.ru:
Саргису 28 лет. Он вместе со своей семьей проживает в деревне Памбак, Лорийского региона. Вся семья Саргиса: родители, брат и жена занимаются сельским хозяйством: разводят коров и свиней.  
Полученную сельскохозяйственную продукцию Саргис реализует и таким образом содержит семью. Молочные продукты он сдает молочным предприятиям региона, а мясо сдает мясным лавкам на рынке. Также каждую весну он продает телят своим односельчанам. 
Саргису необходим кредит на сумму 600.000 драм для закупки на зиму сена и комбикорма для своих коров и свиней.
texts.en: Sargis is 28 years old. He lives with his family in the village of Pambak in the Lori region. Sargis's entire family - his parents, brother and wife - raise cows and pigs. Sargis then sells the products and this is how the family makes a living. Sargis sells milk to the local milk factories and he sells the meat to the butchers at the market. Every spring he also sells calves and piglets to other villagers. Sargis is requesting this loan of 600,000 dram to purchase hey and pelleted fodder for the winter for his cows and pigs.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his farm animals

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es: La señora Virginia tiene una movilidad que la usa como taxi y contrata a un chofer de reemplazo para que maneje la movilidad; su esposo es policia. El crédito lo requiere para la el mantenimiento de su movilidad, chequeo de fluidos, frenos, llantas y motor, pues es  la fuente de ingresos que tiene para ayudar al esposo a cubrir los gastos familiares. Vive en  casa en propia la misma queda  ubicada en la zona de Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz; es casada y tiene cuatro hijos. Es la segunda vez que el cliente obtiene un crédito en IMPRO y también la segunda a través de Kiva.
texts.en:
Sra. Virginia owns an automobile that is used as a taxi, so she hires a driver to operate the vehicle. Her husband is a police officer. The loan she is requesting will be used for vehicle maintenance, as well as to have the fluids, brakes, tires, and engine checked. This vehicle provides a source of income that enables her to help her husband with covering the family expenses. Virginia lives in her own home in the District of Llojeta in the city of La Paz. She is married and has four children.

This is the second time Virginia has obtained a loan from IMPRO, as well as the second time through Kiva.

loans.use: to pay for vehicle maintenance.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 39 and has been in farming in her home area of Kitale for 6 years. Her farm produces maize and beans for the local market. She is married with one child aged 1. She runs a hotel business in the local market to supplement her farming income.

Caroline has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the proceeds from her business will be used to repay the loan and secure the future of her children by giving them a good education. Her focus is to have a farm with six hybrid grades of dairy cows. She adds that the dairy produce will also help improve her hotel business.

Caroline says poor infrastructure in the area is a major challenge in farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 6 children, one of whom is in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (sister and brothers). Margaret has a business of selling electronics. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.   Margaret sells her products in a retail shop. Margaret has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of electronics like socket brakers, flat irons, extension cables, bulbs and radios. She also generates additional income through selling chapattis (type of flatbread). The main business challenges for Margaret include transportation, defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully-stocked electronic shop. Margaret lives in a home that she owns. She has access to both electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food for the family and medication.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of electronics like socket brakers, cables, bulbs, and radios

loans.name: Joaquin

texts.es: El señor  Joaquín es artesano costurero; su esposa se fue a trabajar al extranjero para ayudar económicamente a su familia. El crédito lo requiere para la compra de una maquina bordadora, así podrá mejorar la calidad de sus productos con un terminado perfecto que atraiga al cliente. Vive en casa de sus suegros la misma queda ubicada en la zona  Rió Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto; es casado y tiene tres hijos. Esta es la segunda vez que su solicitud de crédito se canaliza a través de los financiadotes en Kiva.
texts.en:
Sr. Joaquín is a sewing artisan. His wife works abroad in order to help their family financially. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy an embroidery machine so that he can improve the quality of his products. By perfecting the finishing touches on his goods, he will be able to attract customers. Joaquín lives in the house of his in-laws in the District of Rió Seco in the city of El Alto. He is married and has three children.

This is the second time that his loan is being referred to the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase an embroidery machine.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es: La señora Sonia es comerciante de venta de pescados y mariscos semanalmente en la ciudad de El Alto, y viaja al departamento de Santa Cruz una vez por semana para vender su producto. El crédito lo requiere para adquirir una mayor variedad de mariscos y pescados para ofrecer a su clientela. Vive en casa de sus padres la misma queda ubicada en la zona de Río Seco en la ciudad de El Alto; es casada, tiene una hija. Es la primera vez que le cliente obtiene un crédito esperando mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Sra. Sonia is a merchant who sells fish and shellfish every week in the city of El Alto. She travels to the Department of Santa Cruz once a week in order to sell her product. The loan she is requesting will be used to acquire a wider variety of shellfish and fish to offer to her customers. Sonia lives at her parents’ home in the District of Río Seco in the city of El Alto. She is married and has a daughter.

This is the first time she has obtained a loan and she hopes to improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fish and shellfish in bulk.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is married with 5 children aged 6 to 19. He has been a maize farmer for 25 years. He would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

He will use the Kiva loan to cover labor costs and fertilizer costs during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production.
 
With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (sisters). Madina has a business of selling cereals. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Madina  sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Madina has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of groundnuts (peanuts) and beans. She  also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Madina include seasonality and ever increasing prices of cereals.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and also to start going to other villages for cereals. Madina lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food for the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans and groundnuts (peanuts)

loans.name: Leopord

texts.en:
Leopord is married with three children aged 8 to 11. He has been a maize farmer for 7 years. He would like a loan to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for his crop. He will use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and for fertilizer, which is needed to increase his maize production. 

He wishes to invest profits from farming into his business in order to acquire machines and tractors in the future, to enhance his farming capacity.


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: Buy more fertilizer, seeds,pesticides, and pay for labor to grow his crop.

loans.name: Twisungane /ksbg/mrm Group

texts.fr:
Jean Baptiste fait partie du groupe Twisungane/Ksbgg/Mrm. Il a 31 ans et il est marié avec 2 enfants de 3 mois à 6 ans, dont 1 scolarisé. 

Jean Baptiste est agriculteur. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques et payement main d’œuvre pour l’agriculture des tomates. 

Dans les prochaines années, Jean Baptiste voudrait être le grossiste. Avec les profits, Jean Baptiste prévoit d’éduquer et payer les frais médicaux pour sa famille.
texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is a member of Twisungane/Ksbgg/Mrm Group. He's 31 years old, and married with two children, age 3 months to 6 years. One child attends school.

Jean Baptiste is a farmer. He's seeking his first loan from Kiva's partner, ACB, to buy chemical fertilizers and pay for labor for his tomato farming business.

In the forthcoming years, he would like to be the wholesaler. With his profits, he intends to educate and pay medical expenses for his family.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers and pay for labor

loans.name: Pascal

He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer to increase production. With the profits from farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

loans.name: Chi Primus Ngwa

texts.en:
He is 28 years old. He is married and has two children with none of them below fifteen years of age. He lives with his family in a two bedroom apartment in End of Tar, Longla. The death of his uncles who drowned in a river, the death of his mother during childbirth, the death of his sister who left her children in his care and joblessness are some of the sad memories he has.

He joined GHAPE in 2009 and has received and successfully repaid Empowerment Credit just once. He invested this loan in his glycerine business. He used the profit from this business to sponsor his children in school.

Given a loan, he will still invest in the glycerine business. He believes that this business will be a success because he has years of experience in this business. He thinks that this business will be of help to the community in that he will bring the product closer to the people, saving the stress of moving long distances to get glycerine to rub on themselves.

With the proceeds from this loan, he will educate his children, clothe himself and his children and also equip his house. He prefers a GHAPE loan because the interest rates are lower and because of the group system.

loans.use: to buy glycerine, omo (soap) and rubbing oil.

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:

She will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizers to increase production. With the profits from farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

loans.name: Santa Rosa De Lima De Conchacalla Group

texts.es:
En este nuevo desembolso está la Sra. Vicentina, ella tiene 50 años D. edad, la socia es casada y tiene 5 hijos D. 25, 23, 20, 16, 12 años D. edad, La socia es una persona muy trabjadora y tiene varios oficios para poder obtener rentabilidad economica para educar a sus hijos, la socia tiene como principal actividad yla agricultura ella siembra y cosecha maíz, papa, trigo, cebada y aunque este ingreso no es mensual ella hace todos los esfuerzos posibles para generar ganancias en otras actividades como la venta D. queso, ya que la socia tambien tiene ganados y vacas lecheras las cuales producen leche y ella pueD. elaborar queso; la socia también se dedica a la crianza D. animales menores, ella en esta ocasión desea el credito para poder comprar gallinas doble pechuga y cuyes como 50 pares. La socia a futuro desearía poder exportar sus productos pero aun en esta zona no es posible eso ya que no se tienen los contactos para hacerlo, ella dice que vendiendo D. forma minorista y a los compradores frecuentes en la zona no gana mucho y sería una muy buena opcion exportar pero ella como muchos socios no saben como hacerlo. La socia desea el credito para invertir en la compra D. gallinas doble pechuga y D. cuyes 50 pares. 
Las otras socias se dedican a la agricultura, a la ganadería, a la crianza D. animales menores y una D. las socias atienD. su tienda D. abarrotes pequeña.
Las socias se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
In this new loan disbursement is Vicentina. She is 50 years old. She is married and has 5 children who are 25, 23, 20, 16 and 12 years old. She is a hardworking person and has various ways of earning a living in order to be able to obtain financial profitability so she can educate her children. 

Her main activity is agriculture and the planting and harvesting of corn, potatoes, wheat, and barley. Since this not monthly income she puts all her possible efforts into generating earnings from other activities such as selling cheese, because she also has cattle and dairy cows which produce milk and she can make cheese. She also breeds small animals. 

At this time she is asking for a loan in order to buy double breasted chickens and 50 pairs of guinea pigs. 

In the future she would like to export her products even though in this area it is not possible and she does not have the contacts to do it. She says that she is selling retail and to buyers in her area.  She does not earn much and it would be a good option to export but she and other members do not know how to do it. 

She is asking for a loan in order to buy double breasted chickens and 50 pairs of guinea pigs. The other members work in agriculture, livestock, raising small animals and one of the members has a small grocery store The members promise to make their payments on time.

loans.use: to buy double breasted chickens and 50 pairs of guinea pigs

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is married with seven children aged 5 to 22. He has been a maize farmer for 34 years. He would like a loan to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production. Fertilizer is needed in order to increase production.
 
With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crops.

loans.name: Teebah

texts.en: Teebah is 25 years old and lives in Paynesville. She is married and has a four-year-old child who is in school and lives at home. For the past twelve years Teebah has been selling charcoal in her community. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. One of the main problems she faces is the rainy season. She learned this business from her mother. She really likes her business because it always gives her money. She hopes to become a big businesswoman in future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is married with 6 children aged 4 to 15. He has been a maize farmer for 4 years.  He would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow his crop. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow his crop.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, both of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (sisters). Janet has a business of a restaurant. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Janet sells her products from home, by means of retail. 

Janet has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken and Irish potatoes.  She also generates additional income through selling tomatoes and onions. The main business challenge(s) for Janet include seasonality and ever increasing prices of foodstuffs. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked restaurant and also to start a cookery school. 

She lives in a home that she owns where she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken and Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Alipe

texts.en:
Alipe is married with 2 children aged between 24 and 1. He has been a maize farmer for 12 years.  He would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow his crop.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is married and has eight children aged 9 to 27. She has been a maize farmer for 23 years. 

Christine is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow her crop. She will use the loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production.  With profits from her farming, Christine will invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine has four children aged 7 to 21. She has been a maize farmer for 35 years. 

Clementine is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow her crop. She will use the loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production. With profits from her farming, Clementine will invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides.

loans.name: Benji

texts.es:
El socio es el Sr. Benji; el socio tiene 18 años de edad, el socio es soltero, el socio tiene un negocio de venta de ropa,el vende pantalones,polos,blusas y casacas,el vende en forma independiente entregando a diferentes lugares como instituciones y al publico en general,el socio tambien sigue estudiando ingles,por medico de este negcoio el socio quiere salir adelante . El socio desea el crédito para comprar pantalones,polos y casacas al por mayor.

El socio agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
Benji is 18 years old and single.  He has a business selling clothes.  He sells pants (trousers), tops, blouses and jackets.  He makes his sales independently, delivering to different places such as institutions and the general public.  He also continues studying English.  Through this business, he would like to get ahead in life.  Benji would like this loan to buy pants, tops and jackets wholesale.  

Benji is grateful for the support that he is being given and pledges to make his repayments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to buy pants, tops and jackets wholesale.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos es abogado, trabaja independientemente elaborando tramites como ser: testimonios, manutención familiar y otros. Con el dinero del préstamo hará la refacción de una habitación en su casa para vivir en mejores condiciones; vive en casa propia ubicada en la zona Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz; Carlos está separado y tiene dos hijos. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo en IMPRO esperando mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Carlos is an attorney who works independently preparing documents such as testimonies, family support orders, and other legal instruments. The money from this loan will be used to repair a room in his home so that he can have better living conditions. Carlos lives in his own house in the District of Tembladerani in the city of La Paz. He is separated from his spouse and has two children.

This is the first time he has received a loan from IMPRO. He hopes to improve his family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to pay the cost of repairing a room in his house.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is a farmer in Kitale, Kenya. He is 34 years old and married with 3 children, aged 3 to 9 years. He has been producing maize and beans for the local market for five years. He also runs a second-hand clothing business.

For a new venture into poultry farming, Fredrick has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure poultry birds. He hopes the farming business will help boost his clothing business to wholesale levels. Fredrick mentions that poor infrastructure, coupled with limited finances, are his major challenges.

He says the income from the two businesses will help him with his children's education.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Maristela

texts.es:
La señora Maristela tiene 40 años D. edad, es madre soltera D. un hijo.

Ella se dedica a la costura D. ropa y a la elaboración D. pupusas. Hace tres años su esposo dejo el hogar y desD. entonces, Maristela trabaja para mantener a su hijo y a sus padres que ya estan ancianos.

Maristela con la ayuda D. su hermana, venden todos los días por la tarD. pupusas y en el transcurso del día se dedica a la costura D. ropa. Ella aprendió la costura gracias a sus padres ya que la enviaron a una academia para que aprendiera hace 16 años y eso es lo que ahora representa una fuente D. ingresos para ella y su familia. Los insumos para elaborar las pupusas las adquiere en el lugar más cercano a su vivienda, para luego regresar a su casa y elaborarlas.

Maristela solicita un préstamo a Fundación Campo, para comprar cemento, arena, entre otros materiales y construir un tapial perimetral, para mantener segura y protegida su vivienda, ya que su papá elabora cultivos y estos estarán más seguros. Mas adelante ella espera construir su propia casa junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Maristela is 40 years old.  She is a single mother and has one son.

Maristela sews clothes and makes pupusas.  Her husband left her three years ago and, since then, Maristela has worked to support her son and her parents who are now elderly.

With the help of her sister, Maristela sells pupusas every afternoon and, during the day, she sews clothes.  She learned how to sew thanks to her parents as they sent her to a school to learn 16 years ago and now this has become a source of income for her and her family.  She acquires the supplies she uses to make her pupusas from the closest place to her home.  She then returns home and makes them.

Maristela is requesting a loan from Fundación Campo to buy cement, sand and other materials in order to build a perimeter wall to keep her home safe and protected.  Her dad grows vegetables and these will be safer.  In the future, Maristela hopes to build her own house together with her family.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and other materials to build a perimeter wall

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 47 years old, married, and has seven children, four of whom attend school.  She is a farmer in Kitale, Kenya, which she has been doing for over 10 years. Her farm produces maize and beans, which she sells to the local market. Her family relies fully on farming for their upkeep.

Agnes is requesting a loan for 90,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo, which she will use to purchase and insure a dairy cow for 52,000 KES and purchase poultry birds for a venture into poultry farming for 38,000 KES. She hopes that the boost in her farming income will help her feed her family as well as educate her children.  Agnes states that diseases are the major limitation in the farming business.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members including her father. Irene owns a restaurant. She has been in this business for over ten years, and she works six days out of every week. Irene sells her products from home, by means of retail. She also generates additional income through rental rooms.

Irene has requested a loan for 600,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, rice, chicken and cassava. The main business challenge(s) for Irene include seasonality and ever increasing prices of food staffs. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked restaurant and also to start outside catering. Irene lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding her family and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, rice, chicken and cassava

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: La señora Nancy trabaja como auxiliar contable en una de las asociaciones de jubilados constructores de  La Paz. El crédito lo requiere para la operación de riñones de su hermano, quien no tiene ningún tipo de seguro y está sumamente enfermo. Nancy vive en casa de sus abuelos la misma queda ubicada en la zona de Pasankeri en la ciudad de La Paz; es divorciada y tiene dos hijos. Este es el tipo de crédito que definitivamente debe ser atendido prontamente y se lo canaliza a través de Kiva porque llega a los corazones de los financiadores.
texts.en:
Sra. Nancy is employed as an assistant accountant for one of the associations of retired construction workers in La Paz. The loan she is requesting will be used to pay for her brother’s kidney operation. He does not have any insurance and is gravely ill. Nancy lives at her grandparents’ home in the District of Pasankeri in the city of La Paz. She is divorced and has two children.

This type of loan definitely deserves a quick response, so this request is being referred to Kiva so that it will reach the hearts of its lenders.

loans.use: to pay for her brother's operation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bonnie fish by the carton for her business.

loans.name: Abishyizehamwe No 1 /kbz Rhh Group

texts.fr:
